newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: IATA chief unhappy with Europe air traffic reforms.
newsitem.headline: IATA chief unhappy with Europe air traffic reforms.

text.p: The head of the world airlines body said proposed reforms of European air traffic management, due to be passed this week, would give airlines and passengers a raw deal and fail to resolve congestion bottlenecks.

"If they hope to appease us with this package, they will be sorely disappointed," Pierre Jeanniot, director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) grouping 254 airlines, said in a statement on Friday.

"We need a genuine commitment by all European states to design and manage their airspace collectively. What we need and deserve is a system designed to meet customers' needs, not this dubious Valentine card."
IATA said proposed reforms to strengthen the Eurocontrol Agency were due to be approved by the 35 member states of the European Civil Aviation Conference (ECAC) on February 14.

Jeanniot said the proposals were not enough to create an efficient, centralised air traffic management system in Europe and only satisfy national political interests. The Eurocontrol Agency needed more authority to resolve congestion bottlenecks.
